RESPIRATORY.TITLE: Respiratory Emergencies
RESPIRATORY.KEY_TAKEAWAY_DESC: Respiratory emergencies, like asthma attacks or choking, require prompt action. Learn the essential steps to handle these situations and save lives.

CHOKING_ADULTS.TITLE: Choking for Adults
CHOKING_ADULTS.DESCRIPTION: Follow these simple and effective steps to respond to choking in adults, ensuring safety and timely action. By applying this techniques, you can increase the chance of successfully relieving the obstruction and preventing further complications.

STEPS.title: Check if the Person Can Cough, Speak, or Breathe
description: If the person cannot cough, speak, or breathe, proceed with the Heimlich maneuver. If they can do any of these, encourage them to cough to clear the airway.

STEPS.title: Stand Behind the Person and Wrap Your Arms Around Their Waist
description: Stand behind the choking person and wrap your arms around their waist for support.

STEPS.title: Make a Fist and Position it Just Above the Belly Button
description: Make a fist with one hand and place it just above the person's belly button, at the center of their abdomen.

STEPS.title: Grasp the Fist with the Other Hand and Perform Quick, Upward Thrusts
description: Grasp your fist with the other hand and deliver quick, upward thrusts. The motion should be sharp and forceful to expel the object blocking the airway.

STEPS.title: Alternate with 5 Firm Back Blows If the Heimlich Maneuver Fails
description: If the Heimlich maneuver is unsuccessful, alternate with 5 firm back blows between the person's shoulder blades using the heel of your hand.

STEPS.title: Repeat Until the Object is Expelled or the Person Becomes Unresponsive
description: Continue alternating between abdominal thrusts and back blows until the object is expelled or the person loses consciousness.

STEPS.title: If Unresponsive, Begin CPR and Call Emergency Services
description: If the person becomes unresponsive, immediately begin CPR and call emergency services.

CHOKING_BABIES.TITLE: Choking For Babies
CHOKING_BABIES.DESCRIPTION: Follow these simple and effective steps to respond to choking in babies, ensuring their safety and well-being. By using gentle and appropriate techniques, you can help clear the obstruction and restore normal breathing.

STEPS.title: Check if the Baby Can Cough, Cry, or Breathe
description: If the baby cannot make a sound or breathe, proceed immediately with first aid steps.

STEPS.title: Position the Baby Face Down on Your Forearm
description: Place the baby face down along your forearm, with the head lower than the chest, supporting their head and neck.

STEPS.title: Deliver 5 Back Blows
description: Using the heel of your hand, deliver 5 firm back blows between the baby's shoulder blades.

STEPS.title: If Unsuccessful, Turn the Baby Face Up
description: If the back blows don't expel the object, turn the baby face up, supporting their head and neck.

STEPS.title: Perform 5 Chest Thrusts
description: Place two fingers in the center of the baby's chest (just below the nipple line) and perform 5 quick chest thrusts.

STEPS.title: Repeat Until the Object is Expelled or the Baby Becomes Unresponsive
description: Alternate between back blows and chest thrusts until the object is expelled or the baby becomes unresponsive.

STEPS.title: If Unresponsive, Begin Infant CPR and Call Emergency Services
description: If the baby becomes unresponsive, begin infant CPR and call emergency services immediately.

MILD_ASTHMA.TITLE: Mild Asthma Attack
MILD_ASTHMA.MODAL_TITLE: Mild Asthma Attack: First Aid Steps
MILD_ASTHMA.DESCRIPTION: Follow these steps to help manage a mild asthma attack, ease breathing difficulties, and prevent further complications. Immediate action can improve comfort and prevent worsening symptoms.

STEPS.title: Help the Person Sit in a Comfortable Position
description: Have the person sit upright in a position that allows for easier breathing.
Encourage them to remain calm, as stress or panic can worsen the attack.

STEPS.title: Assist with the Rescue Inhaler
description: If the person has a rescue inhaler, help them use it correctly. Usually, they need 2 puffs for relief.
Make sure they breathe in slowly and deeply after each puff to ensure the medication reaches the lungs.

STEPS.title: Encourage Slow, Deep Breaths
description: Guide the person to take slow, deep breaths to help open the airways and calm their breathing.
This can reduce feelings of breathlessness and prevent rapid breathing from intensifying the attack.

STEPS.title: Monitor for Improvement
description: After using the inhaler, monitor the person's condition. If their breathing improves and they feel better, continue to observe them.
If there's no relief after 5 minutes, or if symptoms worsen, call emergency services immediately for further assistance.

HYPERVENTILATION.TITLE: Hyperventilation
HYPERVENTILATION.DESCRIPTION: Follow these steps to help manage hyperventilation, reduce anxiety, and restore normal breathing patterns. Quick action can help the person regain control and prevent complications.

STEPS.title: Encourage the Person to Sit Down and Relax
description: Have the person sit in a comfortable position to avoid fainting or worsening symptoms.
Encourage them to relax and focus on their breathing.

STEPS.title: Guide Them to Breathe Slowly and Calmly
description: Instruct the person to breathe slowly through their nose and exhale gently through pursed lips, like blowing through a straw.
This technique helps slow down rapid breathing and restore normal oxygen levels.

STEPS.title: Reassure and Stay Calm
description: Offer reassurance and stay calm to help reduce anxiety.
Anxiety can worsen hyperventilation, so maintaining a calm environment is crucial.

STEPS.title: Seek Medical Advice if Symptoms Persist
description: If the person continues to hyperventilate or exhibits signs of distress (e.g., dizziness, confusion), seek professional medical help.
Persistent hyperventilation may require further evaluation and treatment.
